Questions:
To convert the given physics text into properly formatted LaTeX, we need to structure it clearly and use appropriate mathematical notation. Here's how you can present the problem in LaTeX:

```latex
\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{amsmath}

\begin{document}

\textbf{Problem:}

A stone is dropped from a height of 19.6 m above the ground, while a second stone is simultaneously projected from the ground with sufficient velocity to enable it to ascend 19.6 m. Determine when and where the stones will meet.

\textbf{Solution:}

Let:
\begin{itemize}
    \item \( h_1 = 19.6 \, \text{m} \) be the initial height from which the first stone is dropped.
    \item \( v_0 \) be the initial velocity of the second stone projected upwards.
    \item \( g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) be the acceleration due to gravity.
    \item \( t \) be the time in seconds after the stones are released.
\end{itemize}

The position of the first stone as a function of time is given by:
\[
y_1(t) = h_1 - \frac{1}{2} g t^2
\]

The position of the second stone as a function of time is given by:
\[
y_2(t) = v_0 t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2
\]

To find when and where the stones meet, set \( y_1(t) = y_2(t) \) and solve for \( t \).

\end{document}
```

This LaTeX document sets up the problem clearly, defines the variables, and provides the equations needed to determine when and where the stones meet. Note that the actual solution to the problem is not provided, as per your request.
